												Imagine with me, if you will.  You are leader of a small but prosperous empire, controlling roughly two dozen small star systems.  You and your allies have been at war with the most powerful civilization for years, and you've managed to gain the upper hand.  A long and costly war has cost you several star systems and most of your fleet.  Finally, they agree to peace.  You sign the papers, and begin to focus on internal affairs.As you check your intelligence briefings, you notice that another empire has been building up their military.  Significantly.  As it stands, the Yor have four to five times as much firepower as the rest of the nations put together, as well as a much larger population.  They begin to greedily prey upon the weaker nations, demanding tribute or conquering them.You halt all social and military production, and begin pouring all of your resources into your R&D projects, developing weapons and shields specialized to counter the growing threat.  One by one, your allied nations fall to swarms of powerful Yor ships.After the research had advanced sufficiently, you empty your coffers and upgrade your small fleet, and purchase some additional cruisers.  You position your fleet on the Terran-Yor border and wait.Its time.  Your destroyers flash across the border, seeking out the numerically superior Yor fleets and engaging them.  Terran ships begin to explode, but the Yor are technologically inferior, and they explode faster.  War erupts across the galaxy as civilizations pick their sides.  A galactic conflagration begins.Behind your destroyers, fleets of heavily-escorted troop carriers descend onto Yor worlds, crammed with billions of troops.  Tens, then hundreds, of billions die as your begin to inch your way towards the Yor homeworlds.  Your war machine keeps turning, producing dozens of sophisticated warships.Eventually, Icos itself falls.  You survey your vast empire, won with the blood of countless billions.  Your huge fleet dwarfs all others.  Your allies are afraid of you.  You've positioned fleets on all of your borders, backed up with troop ships.Then you realize: you've become what you set out to destroy.This is Galactic Civilizations.

												Apparently I'm not saying anything new about this, since it's so highly rated and regarded already, it seems, but nonethless:A game that I have played, stopped playing, and come back to playing again many times over the years. I've enjoyed it a lot, and for some reason a big title or two will come out and I'll eventually forget about galactic civ. for a while, and then eventually  I'll stumble upon it... always surprised by how much I enjoy playing it, time and again.It lacks some of the graphical 'bells and whistles' of a Civ-type of turn-based strategy game, but as any player of ck2 knows, what a game lacks in polish can be very much made up for in actual game content and replayability. The depth of galactic civ (and ck2, for that matter) makes civilization look like simplistic child's play (unplayable to me, as a by-product) in comparison. Distinctive differences/cool elements of the game:- Skill trees are actually unique to every race.- fully customizable ships (designing ships became one of my favorite elements of the game early, to my surprise).- plot/narrative elements that differ game-to-game, making it very replayable.- Races themselves are fully customizable, adding another layer of replayability and depth to the game's customization.On the downside, it has many layers of things to control and 'develop,' so to someone coming to this from civ or simpler games of that nature, galactic civ could be daunting, by all means, even overly so. This is a game for a real turn-based strategy-lover, who wants to have a depth of 'control' that might be beyond the average gamer, whoever or whatever that even means...?I'd say for a strategy-lover (someone who likes games like ck2, europa universalis, etc.) it's a must have regardless of price (I don't think it's more than $20, this far from publication). If you're a civilization/spore lover and you're worried this might go a little too deep and not have the 'sheen' you look for in a game, wait for it to go on sale, as it does every so often, and get it for $5, and give it a shot; Who knows? The developers clearly labored over it with love, and put in a lot of good work in making a very fine game (as I see it).

developing great strategy games.There're no other games with the same variety of strategic options as this game has.You choose your race from 10 preset ones or create your own custom race, pick your political party with various bonuses and aim for victory on randomly generated galaxy through negotiations or wars with other races, you can also choose which victory condition so it's replayability is quite high!There're so many options you can choose while playing, such as alignment of your civilization (good, neutral, evil), form of your government, and you can adjust your tax rate, the ratio of your government spending and its distribution to 3 categories : ship, building, research.The most fun part is ship design, this allows you to create your own ship by combining various components!You can also choose what type and how many of weapons or shields or engines to mount on your ship.This game needs many requirements to declare war compared to other 4x games, which makes the game progress slower than other 4X titles, crush of civilizations begin around 100th turn.The range your ship can travel from your friendly planets is determined by the amount and efficiency of life-support modules on your ship, which means you need to research better ones to colonize or invade further planets.Turning citizens to colonists or soldiers for invasion means less workers and tax payers on your planet so you need enough population and your people's approval which affects planet's population growth rate for maintaining your economy.Espiionage is also important to know which type of weapons and shields your enemies use.Yes, interplanetary warfare costs so many resources including manpower...The only annoying drawback is that it needs a Stardock account before activation...its old menu, interface and graphic aren't much concern for playing.This is definitely a great strategy worthy playing.Thanks to its tutorial and many players' guide, getting the rule below)==============================古い作品ながら宇宙が舞台のターン制4Xゲームの中では今でも傑作、ストラテジー系ゲームの製作に定評のあるStardock製で他作品に無い戦略性の高さが売りです。既存の10種族か自作のカスタム種族を使い、ランダム生成される銀河を舞台に他種族との交渉や戦争を通して勝利を目指す、要はシド星の宇宙版です。複数の勝利条件からどれを選ぶかも自由で、何度でも遊べます。プレイ中も自種族の属性(善・中立・悪)や政治形態など様々な選択肢が用意され、また税率や政府支出額と造船・建設・研究の3分野への配分率も調節できます。最も楽しいのは船の設計、部品を組み合わせ自分だけの宇宙船を作成可能、搭載する兵器の種類や量も調整できます。他の作品に比べ戦争の条件が厳しく、ゲームの進行は他の同ジャンル作品に比べ遅めです、戦争には100ターン前後かかります。宇宙船の行動可能範囲は生命維持装置の搭載量と性能で決まるため、遠くの星への入植や侵攻には高性能のものを開発しないといけません。また徴兵や入植により惑星の人口＝労働力と納税額が減るので、人口と人口増加率に関わる支持率を一定に保つ必要があります。更に敵種族の装備を知るため諜報活動も重要です。難点はStardockのアカウントが必要なこと、一昔前のインターフェース周りとグラフィックはプレイに支障をきたす程ではありません。チュートリアルと多くのユーザーが書いたガイドがあり定石を覚えるのは簡単です。間違いなくプレイする価値がある作品です。

												This thumbs down is for the Steam version of GCII: UE (although I haven't played the GoG version so I could likely give it a thumbs down as well). The game-play/mechanics are actually very fun and well-designed but, there's a major problem that prevents me from truly enjoying it--the 2GB Virtual Memory limitation of 32 bit applications.I love 4X games. Specifically, I love playing 4X games on the largest possible map with the maximum number of opponents and the highest density of resources (in this case planets, stars, asteroids and other celestial bodies). I play 4X games this way so I can shape the game-world to my liking. Unfortunately, that is impossible in this game.Because this game was developed as a 32 bit application, its VM maxes out at 2GB. This is a huge problem. After a 100+ turns (sometimes fewer) the game will crash because it runs out of VM. I tried a 4GB patcher on the application with no luck. I did manage to get a game past 500 turns by playing on the very lowest graphics settings but, after a point I still encountered the VM crash.I suppose my biggest mistake was buying this game on Steam. From what I've read, it appears that using a 4GB patcher will work on the GoG version but, not on the Steam version. If you enjoy playing massive 4X games that last for 100s of hours/turns--don't buy this game unless you are willing to pick it up on GoG and patch it to use 4GB of VM.

												I decided to pick up a new 4x space game after pouring many hours into Endless Space. Endless Space lacked complexity and I searched for a more in depth game. Galactic Civilizations 2 fulfill that criteria. I started playing this in 2015 so I have no nostalgic feelings for it. The game is quite good and fun despite its age and limitations, in fact it is the best 4x space game I have played so far (other space 4x I've played are MOO2, Endless Space and Sword of the Stars). Take a good look at the pros and cons because some points might put you off.FeaturesGrid-based mapYou are not restricted to starlanes. You can go anywhere you want. Trade routesFeighters will fly from planet to planet generating more money when they are further away from your planet. They can be attacked.EspionageGet intel and placing spies inside enemy buildings will cripple their production or research depending what building type is being sabotaged.AlignmentYou have a choice to be evil, neutral or good. Races with similar alignments tend to have better relations with eachother and will grant you unique alignment tech and bonuses.United planetsYou will vote on proposals once every year. These could turn into laws if they get the majority of votes.Minor RacesThese are independent races which do not seek to expand and conquer. They are mainly there for trading purposesPoliticsVery thin feature in terms of depth but it spices up the game. Choose your party and government. Changing governments will grant you economic bonuses but will need a higher approval rating to stay in power as the leading party. Multiple victory conditionsSphere of cultural influenceTaking over planets by overlapping it with your area of cultural influence.Tile based systemPlanets contain tiles. Each tile can house one building. A planet's class determines the tile limit.Pros+A.IGalciv 2 has a good AI which becomes more intelligent instead of getting more OP by stats up till Tough difficulty setting. This game has the best AI I've encountered in any 4x game. Races will make alliances with smaller Civilizations to pounce larger ones, they will attack Civilizations which are under siege to take a part of the pie or use spies for destabilization before going in for the kill. They will ask for help when they are under attack or let you know they will declare war to a Civ if you do so. They rarely take any suicidal or crazy decisions. Civs will properly make use of ships and technology given to them.+DiplomacyDiplomacy is solid. It is not gimmicky but very functional. You might trade money, influence, treaties, technology, ships and planets besides the relation factors which determines your relation with that civ. Building up your relations is important for maintaining peace and increases your chance of survival significantly. Other 4x games have the same diplomacy system but it always felt insignificant or ineffective in those games unlike this one. The game is designed in such way that there is no way around diplomacy. The AI is competent at trading and extorting money.+Empire buildingThe main focus of the game is on empire building and comparable to the Civilization series. There is a good developing pace of your empire. Also, there's apparently no way to not have an active fleet.Eventually I wanted to see if there were any keyboard shortcuts I didn't know about. The options don't have a keybinding menu, so I tried to check online. That's when I learned that GalCiv2 breaks the Steam Overlay. The Steam version was released over three years ago, and they still haven't fixed it?After closing the game so I could open a web browser, I checked to see if there was some way to get the Steam Overlay working. What I found was a thread in the Stardock forums where someone asked how to fix it, and the game's community descended on them like a swarm of piranha. Apparently, like EA and Ubisoft, Stardock has its own Steam knockoff. They also have a rabid fanbase that practically worships the developers. Put those two things together, and you've got a forum full of crazies calling for the developers to sabotage the Steam version to try to drive people to use the local knockoff.That killed off the last bit of interest I had in the game.My personal recommendation would be to buy Master of Orion 1+2 from GOG instead. 												To hear more of my thoughts on this game, check out the episode on Game Hoard Podcast[gamehoardpodcast.com]GameplayAs the name might imply, Galactic Civ II plays a lot like the Civilization series. This is definitely not a bad thing and Galactic Civ II expands on the formula in interesting ways. Rather than just unlocking new units, new technologies unlock new ship parts that you can use to design your own ships. Want a slow moving transport with tons of armor? Build it. Want a super fast fighter that can zip across the galaxy and deal out damage but goes down in one hit? Go for it. I really enjoyed this aspect of the game and found that it made combat very rewarding.Another great aspect of the game is the fantastic AI. I really got the sense that the AI players actually know how to play the game and aren't successful just due to unfair bonuses, as is sometimes the case in 4X strategy games. This is important because the game completely lacks multiplayer, which is a strange omission, even with the age of this game.Overall, it's a lot of fun to just start a random map and begin conquering the galaxy. There are lots of different victory conditions and lots of strategies for pursuing them. I won with a mix of military strength and focus on culture to win an influence victory, but was simultaneously pursuing an ascension victory, which requires capturing energy from ascension crystals scattered around the map.Unfortunately, I didn't find the campaign very fun or interesting. All missions seemed to rely on military strategy alone but didn't even start you off with military technology. The result was a slow and clumsy build up to a strategy-less conflict. I spent the majority of my time in the sandbox mode, as I expect is true of most players.PresentationBoth the art and sound in Galactic Civ II is good, but not great. It's all fairly standard sci fi fair and feels pretty derivative and uninspired. These aren't very important aspects to me in a turn-based strategy game, so I was happy to play while listening to my own music. Presentation is definitely a major differentiating factor between this game and the Civilization series.One good aspect of the presentation is that the parts you use in building ships actually animate differently, with shields and weapon systems having different effects during battle.Also, don't expect much in the way of a riveting story.OverallI really enjoyed my time with Galactic Civilizations II and it really does hit that "one more turn" paradigm. If you are looking for a space-based 4X strategy game, Galactic Civ II will definitely scratch that itch and you can have a lot of fun building up your empire

												Everyone worth their salt knows that in the space-heavy 4x games the titles Masters of Orion 1 and 2 are a fundamental part of the genre's the foundation. Galactic Civilizations II manages to continue on those footsteps with it's own twist. I remember playing this one back in the days, a lot. The hours I have on this title here in Steam aren't actually truthful in that regard. However just recently I started playing GalCiv II again, and it still hooks me in like a happy salmon. Even after all these years the graphics are still "ok", as at least I didn't feel distracted by it from the gameplay. And oh boy what gameplay it is. It's your basic space empire simulator with managing colonies, building space stations, trading and diplomacy with other empires, building fleets of spaceships and watching them explode in hails of über-deadly weapons fire of the future. There are a lot of little twists around this main concept though. You can design your own ships, not just the loadouts but also their outlook to a surprisingly great detail. The technology tree and decisions you take incorporates some rudimentary ethics, and you can steer your empire towards good, neutrality or evil and receive technological advances accordingly. There's a storyline campaign which I haven't managed to ever finish, I guess it's a nice attempt of creating content. However free-for-all type random play is what this game excels in my opinion.There have been quite a few mentions of bugs and crashes in the reviews, but I haven't noticed any such behavior except when alt-tabbing to windows from the game. A minor point is also that you will need to register your game at some Stardock service - give them your email address and game key - to be able to play the game. I know this can upset some potential players, and I agree it's a stupid remant of ages past. However at least for myself the registration process took less than a minute and I've never received a singly spam message from Stardock.All in all, well worth it if you're into the 4x genre and can see past the slightly dated graphics and UI.

												In a word: Addictive. Yes, addictive in that terrifying, inescapable, "just-one-more-turn" way. Galactic Civilizations II is what you get if you take Master of Orion II, expand it so that the galaxy, tech tree and ship customisation are roughly a hundred times as huge without ever becoming boring, bump the graphics up to a standard still respectable today for a TBS, give each civilization some serious make-or-break differences (hint: the Drengin and the Yor almost always end up dominating most of the galaxy that ISN'T YOU), and shove it out there to give almost every other space-based TBS a serious poke in the eye.Galactic Civilizations II, made even better by its two expansions Dark Avatar and Twilight of the Arnor, allows you to build up a massive, sprawling interstellar empire, then throw the universe into chaos by stomping rough-shod all over everybody else's massive, sprawling interstellar empires. Each race has its own personality which helps (or hinders) it in its dealings with its various neighbours. Depending on your chosen path, your ethical choices, your research direction and your custom ship designs, you can choose peaceful, violent, subversive or a combination of methods to conquer a galaxy with a large number of customisation options. Galaxies can range in size from miniature star-cluster sized affairs which can be overrun in the space of an afternoon to immense beasts that will probably take weeks to complete a game on. You can pick and choose who shares these galaxies with you; decide how frequent habitable planets will be; choose the difficulty level and the rate at which technologies are researched, and several other options which make each galaxy a unique one. Stars and habitable planets are all renameable for a truly Make-Your-Own-Galaxy experience.Galactic Civilizations II is also still receiving updates from its developer Stardock. The most recent of these seems to have fixed the occasional crash-to-desktop errors which previously occurred, although oddly enough the newest NVidia drivers on Windows 10 seem to generate an "out-of-date driver" error on startup. This error however has no effect on the game itself, which still runs flawlessly on my machine.

												Games are long, and without much action, especially if you use a relatively peaceful strategy-- and peaceful strategies, executed properly, are so massively overpowered that you'd be a fool not to use them. It's not like such strategies even require much finesse; diplomacy will get the job done on any difficulty level, so long as you specialize in it and spend vast amounts of real life time doing it. The ship design system incorporates a lot of meaningless cosmetic elements to try and disguise its fundamental shallowness. Ignore all of the aesthetic stuff and underneath you'll find a very basic system without any art to building a good ship. Just put on the defenses and weapons that counter what your enemy has and that's it. Due to the lack of tactical combat, ships will all fight the same way no matter what kind of weapons they're armed with. Economic management is tedious and ultimately irrelevant in face of the fact that, if you're using a peaceful strategy, you can ultimately build whatever you want and then get the AI to pay for it using the diplomacy system. I'd say skip this one and find yourself a more interesting 4x.

Those were turn based battles ... but I suppose they could do the Star Wars Empires route and go RTS. Either way,  I think scaling the game so you can either macro-manage and watch quick battle outcome, or choose which specific battles you'd like to fight tactically woud be a neat change.  For those looking for a shorter term change of pace at low cost I recommend Civ IV with the Star Trek mod.  Anyway, after all the meandering, GalCiv is still the best 4x game available and if you can get it on sale you won't be sorry you spent the money. 												I'm a huge fan of empire building and 4X genre (such as Galactic Civilizations II, Endless Space, etc) and despite owning several titles, I've never really got around to playing any of them... until now.With that in mind I have no real base of comparison with other games in the 4X genre, which in case you were wondering stands for 'explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate'. I somehow managed to corner the market on diplomatic translators, which meant no other Civilization could make them - so only I could make and trade them! Nice! Then I discovered the Ship Creator tool in the Shipyard, which allows you to design your own ships. Oh man. The trading and diplomacy looked fairly straight forward, then I was invited to the UP for a Galactic Council vote, which I thought was a nice addition.I think what gives this game a mark of 'good' for me is that I had played for 2 hours and not realised it. Going in a thought it would be a 'time sink' game, and it is, yet it's fun to play. IF I do manage to 'win' at this game, I'll keep it installed and play it again. I have a feeling there's a decent mod community out there, and can imagine that there are plenty of community designed races and ships to use. If you enjoy empire building games, don't mind time sink games, and think you can lead your own alien race to glory... this game is for you.

												Read lots of positive reviews about this one, and given the high metascore, I thought I'd give it a try. However the game lost all appeal once I realized that the tech progress is completely linear. You are presented with a huge tech tree, lots of different buildings and other improvements, but they're all completely boring. It's just like, +1 armor, +2 armor, +3 armor. 1+ economy, +2 economy, and so forth. NO nonlinearities, NO interesting synergies to be seen whatsoever, but these are what makes 4X games complex and interesting! The game mechanics really lack imagination, which is a problem I see with lots of Stardock titles. With Legendary Heroes, the lack of complex R&D mechanics is mitigated by the roleplaying system which manages to keep the game interesting. In Sins of a Solar Empire, the linear mechanics are fine because it's an action- and speed-oriented RTS title. But GalCiv, that's just as dull as it gets.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Easily one of the best Strategy Games I've ever played, particularly if we isolate that to 4x Turn Based Games.  I first bought GalCivs II when it was new and after a bit of a learning curve (Having never played a Turn Based Strategy Game at that time) I figured out just how amazing the game actually was.  The ability to customize your faction in almost every aspect, plus continue to develop it down the path you see fit, provides an excellent replayablity and immersion.  The ship designer even allows you to recreate designs from some of your favorite Sci-Fi tales, or develop your own line to help crush the galaxy.  The ability to watch fleet battles was a huge plus, and the game's soundtrack is exceptionally easy to modify if one wants to mix it up after hours of playing.  Once I saw a chance to pick up the Ultimate Edition for 75% off, I bought it in a heartbeat and put in another full game or two.  I've had a number of games in the past taking months to complete on the largest map settings, so the increase in maximum size and depth of the factions only made things better.  The option to customize your enemies ships and faction name sets the stage to truly create your own sci-fi epic, for those you find themselves essentially role-playing such immersive games.In short, I can't reccomend this game enough, as it is a brilliant buy and at an affordable cost.  Even better, one doesn't necessarily need a high-end computer to run the game, despite its high entertainment value!

												Galactic Civilizations II (or GalCiv, as it's affectionately called) is the overall best space 4X available.  There are others which do individual pieces better, but none which match the whole polished package provided by Stardock.  One thing Stardock does particularly well - at least as well as Firaxis with CIV and CiV - is their expansions - and you should play GalCiv with all of them enabled for the full experience. You can also download ship sets made by others and import them into your game; designs based on popular SciFi universes abound.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												Seems like your typical 4X game.  Fly around, meet new people, and take their stuff.  There's much more to it than that, though.  The AI is exceptional.  At higher difficulty levels it's smart, adaptive, and even cunning in a way a lot of human players aren't.  It also doesn't discriminate between player and AI since computer players are as likely to screw each other over as they are to go after you.  AI races play to their strengths and try to avoid exposing their weaknesses. - Militaristic races will hit you with powerful ships, economic races bribe others into attacking you, and diplomats form coalitions to take you down.  The game is also very customizable - It comes with its own editing utilities (though you do have to look for them) and designing your own races and ships using the ingame designer is easy but powerful.  My only complaint is that it lacks any real multiplayer capability - If it had that, it would be close to the perfect game.

												After almost 300 hours, I decided to update my review.Pros-You can customize everything, from government type to ships to starting bonuses and tax rate to what % of budget you want to spend on research, building improvements, and building ships-Diplomacy system is fun, and you can improve your diplomacy ability-Extensive and asymmetrical tech tree-Runs well on♥♥♥♥♥♥laptops not meant for gaming, although you'll get lag on battles (which you'll skip anyways, but I'll get to that)-Control over almost every aspect of your empire, lots of random events with different effects-exploring is fun and you can find anomolies which give you small bonuses that add up after a while-You can absolutely trash the AI via hardcountering, even if they are way more advanced than you-Soldiering skill is fun-Trade is pretty straightforward and useful, improves relations-you can make custom maps, ships, parts, planets, races, portraits, flags, techs, buildings, etc. via the editor and files-easy to mod and edit-ships can gain experience (which grants additional health)-you can control the tactics you use when you invade a planet-long or short games depending on map sizeCons-AI is absolute garbage-AI gets technology regardless of how many research centers it has (which is usually about fifteen scattered throughout their entire empire-AI rarely uses bonus tiles-Ai doesn't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥what you set the technology rate to, or the technology rate only affects you-Ai builds a starport on every one of its planets, and spams ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fighters in flabbergastingly large amounts, regardless of the 3 production their mismanaged planets has-Ai cannot manage a planet to save its life-Did i mention the AI is garbage?-Ai will research the same thing, every time. For example, the Torians will always be 2-3 techs ahead of everyone else in production.-Ai doesn't use defenses. You'll see an early ship with, like, three laser damage and no shields, armor, or missile defense. And it'll be the only thing they produce. I've played games on the harder difficulties where I'm behind 5-6 techs on weapons and I just stick robust hull on a cargo hull, add some shields, and wipe out hundreds of ships with three "platforms"-Ai doesn't use larger ship hulls that i've seen. They research the tech and spam the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ fighters i mentioned above. It comes to the point where you can build one ship that could easily wipe out every other ship in the galaxy in the galaxy.-economy and military score counters are broken. You can have a fleet of above godships, and everyone will still declare war on you and demand tribute every turn because the military score only counts how many damage points your ships have. Economy score is ♥♥♥♥tarded; you can be making 5k profit a turn and the Terran alliance be 5,000,000,000,000 in debt, their research and production flatlined, and their economy score will dwarf yours-With regular planets, you have no chance of building a decent ship this year, even with all factories, quantum fusion reactor (+25/30% production), and manufacturing capital (+100% production) it will still take you 2-3 weeks to build the smallest fighter-With super planets (20-30 quality planets) you can pump out a godship every turn-AI rushes colonization, and even on Immense-size galaxy maps, all planets are colonized within 20-30 turns all planets are taken. A big ♥♥♥♥ you to anyone who wants to play it slow.-games are ridiculously long. Because of above rapid expansion Ai, you will find yourself 100 turns in, not wanting to finish the game because the other races pose no challenge to your navy, but there's so many planets that conquering everyone else would be tedious. -Arcean is the only tech tree worth using-The Yor-mods are trash, which is a shame because its really easy to mod and use mods on the game-only 2-3 basic ship styles-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ OP events literally turning random races into gods, and they still can't be bothered to put so much as a deflector on their ships, and are thus just as weak as everyone elsetl;dr:♥♥♥♥♥♥Ai to match the♥♥♥♥♥♥computers it can run on, worth your money on sale, you'll get your money's worth.

												So, my review is that this game is not recommended. I'll say now, that some people may enjoy it, but personally I didn't. It's a time-sink, but not a particularly fun one. I'll begin with the pros.Pros:Good tech tree. It's interesting, useful, and well-made. It goes quickly, while still lasting quite a while.Customization. You can build ships, create custom races, all of that. I spent most of my time simply re-inacting my books, and seeing how different races of mine would react to those of other universes.Battle screen. If you have two fleets that are in battle, you get a more detailed video of the battle. Though not particularly useful itself, it is enjoyable to watch.Now, for the cons. These are the reasons why I wouldn't recommend this to most people.Cons:Slow start. The beginning feels boring and long-running. Every game begins the same: You have your system, you colonize the one other habitable planet, then you move to the next. And even once you meet another race, you don't have diplomatic incidents to worry about. The worst you could do is sell something important to them by accident. Until you go to war, it's a very tedious and repetetive task.Tactics are useless. Aside from wanting to attack THIS planet instead of THAT one, you don't really need to use tactics. If your ships are strong enough, you just win.Lack of diplomacy. You can't use diplomacy at all. You can pay other races to ally with you, or to declare war on somebody, but that's it.Finally, the game just doesn't fit the role I expected from it. Instead, I got a time sink that I probably won't play for months on end. If you want something that will bring tactics into the game, I'd recommend Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion. For those who enjoy a more basic game when it comes to fleet tactics and diplomacy, you may enjoy this. It has it's ups.

Posted: June 23, 2016
												I keep trying to love GalCiv (I dabbled a little with the first game too).  On paper it's got all the elements of a game I love: 4x check, sci-fi check, it's even turn-based.  Master of Orion II is my favorite game of all time, and I started playing GalCiv I when someone told me that it was what MoO III should have been.  I disagree.  The game is sprawling with completely inadequate tools to help you keep track of what's going on.  I spend half of the time playing searching for that one planet I caught a glimpse of once, and don't get me started on resources and blackholes.  I'm supposed to coordinate multiple colonies building constructors (10-20 turns) and sending them to a resource (20-30 turns) and I can't even find the resource when I want to.  A searchable, sortable database of planets (like the one they had in MoO II!) and resources would go a long way toward making this game playable.  Or since building starbase modules is all constructors do, why don't they just ask which resource I want to go to when I build them?  You remember how in MoO II when you sent a scout to solar system, it automatically found all the planets in that system?  Not here, my friend.  Even with advanced sensors, it takes weeks to explore a system.  And the auto-explore feature on the scouts does not even try to find all the planets.  A lot of the game seems quirky and gimmicky.  You might think that trade routes would be worth a certain steady amount based on the relative wealth, technology, and resources of the trading partner empires rewarding diversity such that if you're very different than your trading partner you make more, right?  No, they pay off based on the distance between the two worlds- like the rest of your civilization isn't even involved in trade.  So you make most off trade routes if you build all your freighters on just one planet, the one furthest from trading partner regardless of what you do on that planet.  Then the value of the route runs through a cycle.  At first it's of little value and it gradually increases to a maximum then it gradually decreases again and repeats.  What the hell is that?  If they cost a bunch then you had to wait then paid off all in a big lump sum, it would seem like they were going for realism with an age of discovery feel.  But what's this cycle thing?  Steady value seems more realistic for trade between advanced civilizations.From the name alone, the game begs to be compared with Civilization.  But if you're going to compare this game to Civilization, it desperately needs a much better GalCivilopedia because virtually every aspect of the game requires more elaboration than what's present.  Between inadequacies, redundancies, and murkiness, it seems like the designers just can't organize your thoughts.  And the result is frustrating game that rapidly becomes boring.  I understand why people want to say they like it, but I don't understand why they do.

												This game is tediously boring.Par for the course of these kinds of games is that you begin with a very small area and number of units, etc. and must find your way to expansion.  This is always relatively boring at first, but goes quickly since there is little to do and you can click through turns quickly.The make or break point for this category of game is how tedious it becomes once significant expansion occurs.  Do you have to click on everything in the map to see if anything needs your attention every turn or does the game notify you whenever something important happens?  In this area, the game is mediocre.  There are notifications when significant events happen, but I still feel the need to check up on every planet periodically to know how things are going.A huge factor for every game's enjoyability is what aspects come into focus.  Every game has good and bad parts.  The question is, do the good parts shine and the bad parts fade into the background or do the bad parts constantly nag you until you can't enjoy the good parts anymore?  Here the game is mediocre to bad.  What you consider good or bad will depend on your gaming preferences and I don't care to take the time to elaborate, but suffice to say I was not impressed with the balance (despite some quite good features).Another big factor is the interface which is mediocre to bad depending on your adaptability and preferences.  It is never good when you spend as much time finding and clicking buttons as you do making real game changing decisions.A significant factor that made me set this game aside was that the explanations of core game concepts was weak.  I read the manual before I played and also went through the tutorials.  Yet, as I played, I didn't really feel like I knew what was going on in many important aspects.  Some people enjoy figuring out the mystery as they go along.  I do for subtle aspects and tricks.  I most certainly don't for the basic core concepts (especially when having taken the time to read the manual...).There are also a handful of other minor points against enjoying this game but I won't bother to elaborate since this is already a long enough review.  The important point is that with the huge number of games available for cheap today, this one just isn't worth the (extensive, tedious) time to play.As I side note, I do not understand at all the number of positive reviews (almost all of which are little more than "YEAH!! AWESOME!! COOL!!! BEST GAME EVAH!!!!!").  I suppose it takes a certain kind of player to enjoy this title.  Make sure you are one of them before you buy it.

												Look up the definition of "awesome" in the dictionary. When you get to the word, you should see "Galacitc Civilization II: Ultimate Edition" in the 'definition' space, because that's exactly what this game is. I have played space games/simulators/strategy since I could touch a keyboard + mouse, and I can safely say that very little in my experience has come close to the stunning gameplay that GCII has to offer. The only other space game(s) that I feel have a chance of competing against this beast are Sins of a Solar Empire (if you prefer real-time and epic space battles) and Endless Space (if you're wanting a simplified version of GC).The graphics aren't next-gen due to the age of this sequel; but then again, one doesn't play this game for its graphical quality as GCII will prove to you in the long course/progression of a custom match.The economic system is by far the best I've seen in any strategy game I have played (and I play most macro-scale strategy games). You have to carefully learn how to balance the taxation of your population with their overall approval of your empire, as well as how much you spend on the different budget groups (Social, Military, and Research). Sliders and percentages make this easy to understand the moment you open up your Domestic Panel (another great aspect of GCII). Keep in mind however that the more money you might place into a specific sector of your empire will yield different results, which all have their benefits and drawbacks (for example, focusing fiscal policies will return you with superior profit, some average research progression, but little military  unless you're spending your profit on fleets instead of further economic upgrades). Overall, the financial situation presented to the player in GCII is simply stunning in its conception as each choice you make will have an effect on your empire.The Research is kind of standard, depending on how many 4X or macro strategy games you've played (various techs lead into specific tech trees, etc). But the gem of the Research aspect is how it differs between each races (which there are many of by the way) and how there are so many options depending on a number of factors (your race tech tree selection, your research spending, etc). 												The (as of this writing) best iteration of one of the most important 4X franchises, the final version of GalCiv2 brings us much more diversified races; deep tech trees; a unique system of space stations; highly customizable ships; an economy system that is arguably even more important than military strategy; and highly customizable game setups.But the most legendary aspect of the game is its best AI in the business. 												This game has held up incredibly well for it's age.  The graphics are fine for a 4x even today and scale well to modern resolutions.The gameplay harkens back to a time when the focus of 4x was on immersion and fun rather than a vain chase for mathematical balance.  Different factions have unique flavors that aren't necessarily balanced, but who cares--they're still fun to play.  Regular cutscenes add a sense of immersion.  Military and industrial management is very well done with waypoints, governors, and auto-upgrading that lets you skip a lot of micromanaging.  The tech tree allows for many play styles, as the prerequistes for a tech are only techs of the same sort--it would be possible (though not advisable) to research to the highest level of laser weapons without researching any non-laser tech.  And different factions and alignments have unique techs available only to them.I hope the upcoming GC3, currently in beta, lives up to the promise of GC2, and they don't make the mistake Civ 5/BE have made of dropping the little things that make 4x games fun and immersive--cutscenes, victory movies, the possibility of discovering unbalanced strategies, faction personality, diplomatic insults, etc.

												This game is a sleeper for most gamers. It looks cheap and boring on the outside, but what lies beneath its exterior is a massively complex and brilliantly engineered game. I have looked for other games like this, such as Endless Space, Sword of Stars, Sins of a Solar Empire, and no other 4X game, not even Civ 4 or 5 come close IMO.The AI is excellent. The developers didn't want to use artificial bonuses for AI to fill the skill gap between human players and what you typically get with most AI's skills. They actually made it so that the AI is thinking and planning while you are taking your turn, so you don't have to wait around for the AI . to perform all of these calculations, which it does. Often the AI will fight poorly when at a disadvantage however, but I always find adequate and fair challenge when I play from some of the AIs. I haven't played multiplayer, so I don't know how that is. The UI and game flow is smooth in spite of having a ton of complexity. Prepare for an in depth tutorial when you first play this game. Once you get the hang of it, it's wonderful.You can wage war or play diplomatically, try to tech up fast or build a trade empire. There are many different ways to play. I have waged proxy wars where I supply another faction with weapons I designed to be effective vs our common enemy, an enemy that I didn't want to go to war with myself due to my trade routes being too close to their territory. There are just so many situations that can happen and each time you play, there is no guarantee that the same strategy you used before will work again. You have to assess the situation and act accordingly. For example; a faction near me declared war on me, and while I had ships that could fight, they were too slow to intercept the enemy ships, so I scrambled to station them in each of my worlds to defend while I researched warp technology. Those worlds I coudn't get a ship to were lost to the enemy for the time being. After defending for a long time, I sent a small fast attack fleet to strike back eventually leading to their downfall. All the while there where huge wars going on in nearby clusters (clusters of star systems).Some issues I have with the game are that special events can unbalance the game to the point that you may as well surrender. Like a ship with massive damage and defense emerges and and stars to obliterate all of your ships. Or half of your worlds defect and form their own faction, which is cool, but could have been implemented better. These things can be turned off however. Another problem I noticed is that if your game gets minimized, when you try to go back you might get a black screen. Sometimes it resumes the game after waiting other times it seems to stay forever. This game does not like to be minimized. Some say to play in windowed mode to fix, but I hate windowed mode. Lastly, it leaves me wanting more from the graphics and music. These may seem trivial compared to game play, but they are very lacking and the game would be much better with them improved.I had to drop another point off of this game due to it not allowing me to install at an internet caffe. It wanted me to register or fill out this form with tons of info I didn't have on hand. I'm not doing that, I don't need to do that. 8/10

												An oldie but goodie.  I rememember playing this game back on an older machine where it was on a couple of CDs.  I picked it up again on Steam and it still hits the sweet spot.  This is old school 4X that while it doesn't offer all the bells and whistles that more recent games might, still has quite a bit for it's age.  Being the second game in the series(as of the time of this review Galactic Civilizations III has been out for awhile) it doesn't offer a lot of surprises.  It's mostly a refinement of the first one just like the more recent III is a refinement of this one.  If you're familiar with 4X games you'll know what to do.  If you aren't, just set the game on it's easiest setting and test stuff out.  The dumbest level AI is very dumb so it'll be fairly forgiving of mistakes.  Having been out for a long time there's no further support for it but it's also free of any serious bugs as far as I can tell(I've never had it crash on me or do weird things anyways).  Hell, I can't recall any minor bugs.  While a variety of new games in the genre have come out since(Galactic Civilizations III, the remake of Master of Orion, etc) it is nice to go back and look at older games that are key parts of the genre.  And of course being as hold as it is, it's cheap(and if you can get it on sale cheaper still).  Definitely worth the price.

												Look, this game is amazing. I probably had 300 hours played before even getting it on Steam. It's the only worthy successor to Master of Orion 2. 												This game is a sleeper for most gamers. It looks cheap and boring on the outside, but what lies beneath its exterior is a massively complex and brilliantly engineered game. I have looked for other games like this, such as Endless Space, Sword of Stars, Sins of a Solar Empire, and no other 4X game, not even Civ 4 or 5 come close IMO.The AI is excellent. The developers didn't want to use artificial bonuses for AI to fill the skill gap between human players and what you typically get with most AI's skills. They actually made it so that the AI is thinking and planning while you are taking your turn, so you don't have to wait around for the AI . to perform all of these calculations, which it does. Often the AI will fight poorly when at a disadvantage however, but I always find adequate and fair challenge when I play from some of the AIs. I haven't played multiplayer, so I don't know how that is. The UI and game flow is smooth in spite of having a ton of complexity. Prepare for an in depth tutorial when you first play this game. Once you get the hang of it, it's wonderful.You can wage war or play diplomatically, try to tech up fast or build a trade empire. There are many different ways to play. I have waged proxy wars where I supply another faction with weapons I designed to be effective vs our common enemy, an enemy that I didn't want to go to war with myself due to my trade routes being too close to their territory. There are just so many situations that can happen and each time you play, there is no guarantee that the same strategy you used before will work again. You have to assess the situation and act accordingly. For example; a faction near me declared war on me, and while I had ships that could fight, they were too slow to intercept the enemy ships, so I scrambled to station them in each of my worlds to defend while I researched warp technology. Those worlds I coudn't get a ship to were lost to the enemy for the time being. After defending for a long time, I sent a small fast attack fleet to strike back eventually leading to their downfall. All the while there where huge wars going on in nearby clusters (clusters of star systems).Some issues I have with the game are that special events can unbalance the game to the point that you may as well surrender. Like a ship with massive damage and defense emerges and and stars to obliterate all of your ships. Or half of your worlds defect and form their own faction, which is cool, but could have been implemented better. These things can be turned off however. Another problem I noticed is that if your game gets minimized, when you try to go back you might get a black screen. Sometimes it resumes the game after waiting other times it seems to stay forever. This game does not like to be minimized. Some say to play in windowed mode to fix, but I hate windowed mode. Lastly, it leaves me wanting more from the graphics and music. These may seem trivial compared to game play, but they are very lacking and the game would be much better with them improved.I had to drop another point off of this game due to it not allowing me to install at an internet caffe. It wanted me to register or fill out this form with tons of info I didn't have on hand. I'm not doing that, I don't need to do that. 8/10

												This game has held up incredibly well for it's age.  The graphics are fine for a 4x even today and scale well to modern resolutions.The gameplay harkens back to a time when the focus of 4x was on immersion and fun rather than a vain chase for mathematical balance.  Different factions have unique flavors that aren't necessarily balanced, but who cares--they're still fun to play.  Regular cutscenes add a sense of immersion.  Military and industrial management is very well done with waypoints, governors, and auto-upgrading that lets you skip a lot of micromanaging.  The tech tree allows for many play styles, as the prerequistes for a tech are only techs of the same sort--it would be possible (though not advisable) to research to the highest level of laser weapons without researching any non-laser tech.  And different factions and alignments have unique techs available only to them.I hope the upcoming GC3, currently in beta, lives up to the promise of GC2, and they don't make the mistake Civ 5/BE have made of dropping the little things that make 4x games fun and immersive--cutscenes, victory movies, the possibility of discovering unbalanced strategies, faction personality, diplomatic insults, etc.

												With my old GC II box-set I used to play monster custom maps that took as many hours to finish as I spent playing with other games overall. GC II feels like playing a board game that has the size of a football pitch. I kind of like its game mechanics and balance. It includes all the elements of a wide-range strategy gameplay but it does it without going too deep into them. During gameplay it means that you don't get drowned into micro management that is not a bad thing.Ages ago there was a game called Imperium Galactica II that bests this one for me, despite the fact that is more than a decade older, because it included direct control over your planetary and space combat where your decisions could win or lose the battles (with immeasurably smaller maps I must add). With good tactics and right choices you could win against much bigger forces. I miss this "outsmarting" option from GC II where you have automated battles where the outcome has already been fixed before the encounter itself.Anyway, it doesn't make the game any lesser. If you support the idea of LEGOing together your own spaceships and roast the hell out of your opponents with them, it would be hard to find a more capable and fun tool. Damn, you can even build your own death star.
